subject: Re: Update on intelligent Senior QS Font.

messageBody:
Thanks for the critique.

One point that I want to make is that QSJ Block is a QuickScript
Junior font; I intended that no letters 'link', that there be visible
space between - except for the ligatures. This font was intended more
for (my own ;) instructional value rather than as a full-fledged
usable font.
One problem I and some of my friends had was that they couldn't
tell where one character ended and another started.
My intention was to create another version later, named QSS Block,
with full linking between appropriate letters.

That said, I certainly did want to *indicate* the proper joining
spots, and it seems I failed in some places.
There are certainly a lot of combinations to kern together!

I think my main design problem was looking at it on the screen
only; in the future I'll certainly print it out at large sizes with
plenty of text to try to catch these mistakes.

I must say I still don't see the problem with descenders you
mentioned. Just what do you mean by 'negative space'?
I used certain proportions (golden ratio) to create the characters;
the tall characters had a height of 100, the short characters 62, and
the descenders 38 (62% of 62%). This is in accordance with various
widely used fonts, and is *supposed* to be foolproof. My one problem
was in defining the width of a character, since the usual 'm' and 'n'
measures wouldn't work with such a different alphabet.
I decided that the 'rounder' characters would fit a square in the
body line, with a width of 62.

I noticed one problem in "Existing"; the /gi/ (Gig If). The /g/
character can apparently join both at the baseline and the midline, as
can the /i/. The problem is that putting them in this order joins
those two characters at top *and* bottom, which certainly looks odd to
my eyes. When I handwrite this combination I change the /g/ to join at
one spot; the other doesn't reach. Or am I deceiving myself?
I suppose the same is true of the /ir/ (If Roar) combination. and
/gr/ (Gig Roar), even more so.

Anyway, this was a learning experience. I've decided that I'll
create the next version from the ground up, planning the line
thicknesses and locations of the joins *first*, rather than trying to
match them up later, which led to the results you see.
